chapter.title: Structuring CeltiXFire Documents
chapter.synopsis: CeltiXfire documentation is based around small, digestable topics. To facilitate this it only uses a small number of the docbook structural tags..

sect1.title: Top-level Elements
sect1.para: Becuase we strive to keep individual documents as specific as possible, CeltiXfire documents use the article element as their root element. If you are writing a document that you feel needs to be more than an article, consider breaking the topic into smaller chunks. This does not mean you cannot link to other documents, but documents should not have such a large scope that they need to be more than an article.

example.title: High-level View of a CeltiXfire Document
example.programlisting: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE article PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.1.2//EN" "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.1.2/docbookx.dtd"> <article lang="en-US"> <title>Developing a Consumer with CeltiXfire</title> ... </article>

sect1.title: Attributions
sect1.para: CeltiXfire does not use the attribution elements.

sect1.title: Sections
sect1.para: CeltiXfire documents are broken into sections. Generally, a document should have five or less sections. If you need more sections, it may be because the topic for your document is too broad or you need to reconsider how you are chunking the information. Top level sections are denoted using sect1 elements.
Top-level sections can be broken down into 5 or less subsections. Subsections are denoted using sect2 elements.
Like top-level sections, subsections can be broken up into 5 or less block-sections. Block-sections are donted using sect3 elements. Block-sections cannot be subdivided.
While it is considered good practice to supply a descriptive value for the id attribute, it is not required.
shows a more detailed view of a CeltiXfire document.
